;;阿富汗妇女在白沙瓦贫困有志者技能学院 (SANA) 参加裁缝课程，巴基斯坦，2023 年 7 月 13 日。（路透社/Fayaz Aziz）;
;

;在巴基斯坦白沙瓦的一栋小建筑中，一群阿富汗妇女正在观看老师向她们展示如何使用缝纫机; 机器。

;

;该培训计划是由 Mahra Basheer 去年设立的，她看到来自邻国阿富汗的女性人数不断增加。自塔利班于 2021 年掌权以来，阿富汗妇女面临着越来越多的限制和经济危机。

;

;Basheer 创建该计划的目的是为妇女提供养活自己的选择。她教授缝纫、;数字;技能和美容护理。 Basheer 很快发现数百名女性想要加入该计划。

;

;“如果我们获得援助，我认为我们将能够一次培训 250 到 500 名学生，;赋权; 能够在社区中发挥重要作用的女性，”Basheer 说道。

;
;;;2023 年 7 月 13 日，阿富汗妇女在巴基斯坦白沙瓦贫困有志者技能学院参加美容师和化妆课程。（路透社/Fayaz Aziz）;
;

;官员们表示，自 2021 年塔利班接管以来，已有数十万阿富汗人前往巴基斯坦。甚至在此之前，该国就有 150 万登记难民。联合国难民机构表示，这里是世界上此类人口最多的地区之一。

;

;据估计，还有超过一百万人未登记居住在那里。

;

;正在与经济危机作斗争。巴基斯坦政府也越来越担心阿富汗难民的数量。近几个月来，许多阿富汗人被捕。律师和官员表示，她们没有在巴基斯坦生活的正确法律文件。

;

;Basheer 说，她的主要目标是扩大针对阿富汗妇女的业务。但她也将一些巴基斯坦女性纳入该计划，以增加她们在保守领域的选择。

;

;培训计划持续三个月。当她们完成该计划后，妇女们将注意力转向赚取足够的钱来生存。许多妇女开始自己创业。

;

;来自阿富汗的 19 岁女孩法蒂玛 (Fatima) 完成了培训项目。她说她想在白沙瓦开一家美容院。目前，在距离她只有几个小时路程的祖国，它已被禁止。

;

;“现在我的计划是在家里开一家沙龙。然后非常专业地工作，以便我;最终; 为自己开一家非常大的沙龙，”她说。

;

;我是 Gena Bennett。

;

;;星期四，华盛顿史密森国家动物园的大熊猫美香在围栏里吃竹子，2023 年 9 月 28 日。（美联社照片/Jose Luis Magana）;
;
;

;美国国家动物园的三只大熊猫将于 2023 年返回中国十二月初。没有公开迹象表明理查德·尼克松总统签署的长达 50 年的交换协议将继续存在。

;
;
;

;中国专家称国家动物园饲养大熊猫的协议可能会终止显示;趋势;。随着中国与一些西方政府之间的外交紧张局势加剧，随着协议的终止，中国似乎正在慢慢地将熊猫从西方动物园撤回。

;
;

;乔治城大学的丹尼斯·怀尔德称这一趋势“;惩罚性;熊猫外交。”怀尔德指出，另外两家美国动物园近年来也失去了熊猫。苏格兰和澳大利亚的动物园也面临着类似的情况，而且没有续签贷款协议的迹象。

;
;
;

;中国目前通过“合作研究项目”向 19 个国家借出 65 只大熊猫。这些计划的既定使命是更好地保护大熊猫。大熊猫年老时会返回中国，出生的幼崽会在三四岁左右被送回中国。

;
;
;;;2023 年 9 月 28 日星期四，大熊猫天天在华盛顿史密森国家动物园的围栏里漫步。 （美联社照片/Jose Luis Magana）;
;
;
;

;国家动物园大熊猫的离开意味着美国仅存的大熊猫将生活在亚特兰大动物园。该贷款协议将于明年年底结束。

;
;
;

;怀尔德表示，中国可能“试图发出信号。”

;
;
;

;怀尔德指出了双方之间的一些分歧。美国政府已对知名中国公民和官员实施制裁。美国还对中国制造的半导体的进口实施限制。半导体是制造计算设备的重要部件。

;
;
;

;美国官员表示，芬太尼等中国生产的药物正在美国城市出现；美国立法者对中国拥有社交媒体服务 TikTok 持怀疑态度。许多美国人对中国气球飘过美国上空感到愤怒。

;
;
;

;怀尔德表示，中国坚信“北约和美国正在联合起来对抗中国。”

; < /div>;
;

;美国参议院最近也出现了与熊猫相关的紧张局势。宾夕法尼亚州民主党人约翰·费特曼似乎反对中国购买美国农田。他说：“……他们正在夺回我们的熊猫。你知道，我们应该收回他们所有的农田。”

;
;
;

;中国的紧张局势正在加剧。今年早些时候，一只被租借到田纳西州孟菲斯动物园的雄性大熊猫乐乐在二月份突然去世，享年 24 岁。在人类照料下的大熊猫通常可以活到 30 岁左右。

;
;;;大熊猫小七姬在史密森尼动物园的围栏里漫步华盛顿国家动物园，星期四，2023 年 9 月 28 日。（美联社照片/Jose Luis Magana）;
;
;
;

;乐乐的意外死亡引起了中国人的极大愤怒微博等社交媒体服务。人们普遍认为孟菲斯动物园虐待了这只动物及其雌性伴侣丫丫。

;
;
;

;访问孟菲斯的中国官方科学代表团宣布乐乐没有受到虐待，并且死于心脏病。 4月份贷款协议结束后，丫丫按计划返回中国，并在上海机场受到热烈欢迎。

;
;
;

;在美国大熊猫贷款协议50年的历程中，

;
;
;

;“但现在的情况完全不同了，”前美国鱼类和野生动物管理局现任动物园协会主席丹尼尔·阿什说和水族馆。 “我们现在看到的是我们两国政府之间在更高层面上的紧张关系，需要在该层面上;解决;。”

;
;
; < p>;我是约翰·拉塞尔。

; Thu, 05 Oct 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Three Win Nobel Prize in Chemistry for Quantum Dots Discoveryhttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/three-win-nobel-prize-in-chemistry-for-quantum-dots-discovery/7296788.html

;;2023 年诺贝尔奖获奖者公布时使用实验室烧瓶进行解释2023 年 10 月 4 日，斯德哥尔摩瑞典皇家科学院举行化学奖。（摄影：Jonathan NACKSTRAND / 法新社）;
;

;周三，美国三名科学家荣获诺贝尔化学奖。三人因发现量子点而获奖，量子点是一种当今广泛用于制造电子设备和医学成像;显示器;的技术。

;

;瑞典皇家科学院将奖项授予了 Moungi麻省理工学院的 Bawendi、纽约哥伦比亚大学的 Louis Brus 和纳米晶体技术公司的 Alexei Ekimov。

;

;学院表示，这三人因在“具有独特性”的粒子方面的工作而受到表彰; 属性，现在通过电视屏幕和 LED 灯传播光线。”

;

;LED 灯是世界各地使用的电子灯，非常有效地利用能源。

;

;Pernilla诺贝尔奖颁奖委员会成员维通·斯塔夫谢德 (Wittung Stafshede) 表示：“我们在电视上、手机上都有显示屏，里面使用了量子点……”

;
;;;Hans Ellegren（中） 2023年10月4日，瑞典皇家科学院常务秘书长在瑞典斯德哥尔摩瑞典皇家科学院举行的新闻发布会上宣布了2023年诺贝尔化学奖获得者。（REUTERS/Tom Little）;
;

;;什么是量子点？;

;

;量子点是极小的粒子，称为纳米粒子。据说它们的宽度约为人类头发的 1/10,000。当暴露在光线下时，这些点会发出蓝色、红色、绿色或其他颜色的光。它们发出的颜色取决于颗粒的大小。较大的点看起来是红色的，较小的点看起来是蓝色的。颜色变化是由电子在这些小空间中的行为引起的。

;

;物理学家早在 20 世纪 30 年代就预测了这些颜色变化特性。然而，人们花了50年的研发时间才正确控制量子点的尺寸。

;

;Ekimov和Brus是该技术的早期研究人员。 Bawendi 因开发了当今使用的量子点的生产而受到赞誉。

;

;Bawendi 用“非常惊讶、昏昏欲睡、震惊、意外和非常荣幸”来形容他的感受。 Bawendi 补充说，当他开始研究量子点时，他并没有考虑自己的工作的可能用途。

;

;“;动机;确实是基础科学。对世界如何运作的基本理解，;好奇心;？这就是驱使科学家和学术科学家去做他们所做的事情的原因。”他说。

;

;哥伦比亚大学的布鲁斯表示，他没有接听瑞典科学院的电话。早上起床后，他终于在网上看到了这条新闻。

;

;布鲁斯说，他希望量子点的;实际;用途，例如在电视屏幕上创造颜色多年前当他开始这项工作时。

;

;“基础研究很难准确预测其结果，”布鲁斯说。 “这更多的是为了知识库而不是实际材料。但在这种情况下，两者兼而有之。”

;

;Ekimov 是 Nanocrystals Technology 公司的前首席科学家，该公司位于纽约，他于 1999 年开始在该公司工作。瑞典科学院称赞他展示了纳米粒子影响了玻璃的颜色。

;

;当三人在 12 月的颁奖典礼上获得诺贝尔奖时，他们将获得 1100 万瑞典克朗（约合 100 万美元）和一枚金牌。

;

;我是 Dan Friedell。

; Thu, 05 Oct 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Study Finds AI Tools Help but also Hurt Worker Performancehttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/study-finds-ai-tools-help-but-also-hurt-worker-performance/7296498.html
;;2023 年 10 月 4 日星期三 22:05:30 GMT;
;;
;;在这张 5 月 4 日拍摄的插图图像中可以看到 ChatGPT 徽标和人工智能一词， 2023.（路透社）;
;

;一项涉及数百名办公室工作人员的实验发现，人工智能 (AI) 工具可以极大地帮助但也会损害员工的绩效。

;

;人工智能工具在过去的一年里，旨在以人类水平运作的技术大大普及。其中包括 OpenAI 的 ChatGPT、谷歌的 Bard 和微软的人工智能搜索引擎 Bing。

;

;此类工具也称为聊天机器人或“生成式人工智能”，是计算机驱动的系统。它们旨在与人类顺利互动并执行高水平的写作和创造性工作。

;

;近几个月来，这些工具已经证明了产生高质量工作的能力。这导致一些技术专家警告称，生成式人工智能系统最终可能会取代许多行业的工人。

;

;今年，哈佛商学院和其他组织的研究人员进行了一项实验。它的目的是测试人工智能工具如何帮助员工履行日常职责或任务。它涉及来自马萨诸塞州波士顿咨询集团的 700 多名商业顾问，称为顾问。

;

;哈佛商学院最近 ;在“工作论文”中发布了;实验结果。主要研究结果表明，像 ChatGPT 这样的人工智能工具可以极大地提高工作人员的绩效。

;

;例如，研究人员发现，平均而言，使用 OpenAI 最新 ChatGPT 4 工具的工作人员比非 ChatGPT 用户多完成了 12% 的任务。在人工智能技术的帮助下执行的任务完成速度提高了 25%。团队发现使用 ChatGPT 4 的顾问的工作质量提高了约 40%。

;

;研究中使用的工作任务涵盖四个主要领域：创造力、分析思维、写作和说服力。该团队给出了每个领域的工人任务示例。

;

;创造力的一个例子是：“针对服务不足的市场或运动，针对一款新鞋提出至少 10 个创意。”在写作方面，顾问被要求为新产品“撰写带有营销文案的新闻稿”。为了表现出说服力，员工被要求写一封信给员工，解释为什么某种特定产品会击败竞争对手。

;

;哈佛商学院的 Fabrizio Dell'Acqua 是该论文的主要作者。他;讲述了;技术他认为结果特别重要，因为它们表明人工智能工具甚至可以帮助受过高等教育、经验丰富的工人。

;

;“事实上，我们可以;提高;这些高度受过高等教育的工人的绩效。来自顶尖;精英; MBA 机构的高薪高技能顾问……我想说这确实;令人印象深刻;，”Dell'Acqua 说道。

;

;但是，论文还指出了使用 ChatGPT 4 的顾问绩效下降的领域。研究人员表示，对于人工智能工具不擅长完成的任务尤其如此。

;

;在人工智能擅长的任务中，实验表明它“显着提高了人类的表现”，论文 ;说;。但对于 ChatGPT 4 不适合的任务，“人类;过于依赖;人工智能，并且更容易犯错误。”

;

;研究人员报告说，使用人工智能的顾问对于没有充分装备的任务，“与没有人工智能的任务相比，产生正确解决方案的可能性降低了 19%。”

;

;该实验还展示了顾问如何以不同的方式使用人工智能工具来改进他们的工作。研究人员表示，一些工人故意划分任务，有些完全由人工智能工具完成，有些则完全由工人自己完成。其他员工选择使用人工智能来完成所有任务，同时“不断与技术互动。”

;

;该团队表示，公司有效使用人工智能的最大障碍之一是不知道哪些任务可以最好地完成技术。要找到这一点，企业需要进行深思熟虑的研究和培训工作，以便找到人工智能和人类水平工作的正确组合。

;

;我是 Bryan Lynn。

;

; Thu, 05 Oct 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Export Restrictions Causing Food Prices to Risehttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/export-restrictions-causing-food-prices-to-rise/7289271.html
;;2023 年 10 月 3 日星期二 21:55:32 GMT;
;;
;;2023 年 9 月 12 日星期二，人们在肯尼亚内罗毕的一个公开市场购买洋葱.（美联社照片/Brian Inganga）;
;

;在世界许多地方，谷物和食用油等重要食品的价格再次上涨。

;

;观察家表示，这是因为各国已实施出口限制以保护国内粮食供应。他们还将价格上涨归咎于天气状况和乌克兰战争。

;

;卡罗琳·基亚洛 (Caroline Kyalo) 28 岁，在肯尼亚首都内罗毕的一家美发沙龙工作。她在为两个孩子计划膳食时经历了食品价格上涨的情况。自邻国坦桑尼亚限制农产品出口以来，洋葱价格上涨了200%。基亚洛（Kyalo）尝试了另一种洋葱，但这些洋葱也变得太贵了。食用油和玉米粉的价格也在上涨。

;

;所以，她说，“我只是决定每天做饭一次。”

;

;东非拥有肥沃的土地和大量的劳动力。但种植和运输农作物的高昂成本以及缺乏降雨导致当地产量下降。就洋葱而言，联合国粮食及农业组织发现，2014 年，肯尼亚一半的洋葱来自坦桑尼亚。一些贸易商试图从埃塞俄比亚获取物资。其他人已经完全停止销售洋葱。

;

;但蒂莫西·金尤亚 (Timothy Kinyua) 表示，价格已达到七年来的最高水平，并承诺他会出售洋葱。

;

;“这是我们能做到的”没有就做饭。”他说。

;

;;传播食品限制;

;

;约瑟夫·格劳伯 (Joseph Glauber) 就职于华盛顿国际食品政策研究所。他说，坦桑尼亚今年的洋葱限制是食品限制蔓延的一个例子。他称之为“传染病”，或者像传染病一样传播的东西。他的组织表示，19 个国家实施了 41 项食品出口限制。这些限制包括禁令或税收。

;

;印度今年早些时候禁止出口部分大米，削减了世界五分之一的出口市场。缅甸也以自己的出口禁令作为回应。印度也限制洋葱出口。这一行动导致孟加拉国的价格上涨。

;

;西班牙的干燥天气损害了其橄榄作物，导致欧洲买家将目光转向土耳其。但那里的价格上涨导致了出口限制。

;

;最近遭受严重地震的摩洛哥也停止了洋葱、土豆和西红柿等农作物的出口。

;

;;'新常态';

;
;;;由于各国限制出口，粮食价格上涨。归咎于气候变化、厄尔尼诺现象和俄罗斯战争。 （美联社照片/Efrem Lukatsky，档案）;
;

;多年来，食品价格发生急剧变化。 2007年和2008年，大米和小麦价格翻了一番。曾任农业部经济学家的格劳伯表示，变化可能会持续下去。

;

;“我认为波动性增加肯定是新常态，”他说。

;

;例如，俄罗斯和乌克兰都是小麦、小麦、葵花籽油和其他几种对发展中国家很重要的食品的主要供应国。它们之间的冲突干扰了双方的生产。

;

;观察人士称，天气变化也影响着农业。厄尔尼诺现象是南太平洋的周期性暖流。它与世界多个地方的天气变化有关。一些科学家表示，气候变化可能会使厄尔尼诺现象更加严重，影响各地的天气。

;

;例如，印度降雨不足，意味着那里的出口限制可能不会随着 10 月份新稻米的收获而结束。

;

; p>;

;;进口商面临更大风险;

;
;;;Charina 2023 年 9 月 21 日星期四，Em 在马尼拉的一家食品店摆出姿势。（美联社照片/Joeal Calupitan）;
;

;受天气变化影响最大的是严重依赖进口的国家食物。例如，世界银行指出，菲律宾 14% 的食品依赖进口。然而，最近的风暴可能意味着进一步的农作物短缺。 8月份大米价格上涨8.7%。这是上个月涨幅的两倍。

;

;由于价格上涨，菲律宾食品店老板表示他们正在亏损。三十二岁的 Charina Em 在马尼拉 Trabajo 市场拥有一家商店。

;

;“我们不能再省钱了。就像我们工作就是为了每天有饭吃一样。”她说。

;

;Cynthia Esguerra 66 岁，患有多种疾病。她说她必须在药物和食物之间做出选择。

;

;“我只是不担心我的病。我把它留给上帝。我不再买药了，我只是把它放在那里买食物或贷款，”她说。

;

;我是小马里奥·里特

;

;

;

; Wed, 04 Oct 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Three Professors Share Nobel Physics Prize for Study of Electronshttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/three-professors-share-nobel-physics-prize-for-study-of-electrons-/7295311.html
;;2023 年 10 月 3 日星期二 21:55:53 GMT;
;;
;;此组照片拍摄于 2023 年 10 月 3 日星期二，从左至右显示，法语科学家皮埃尔·阿戈斯蒂尼（Pierre Agostini）、科学家费伦茨·克劳斯（Ferenc Krausz）和法裔瑞典物理学家安妮·卢利尔（Anne L'Huillier）。这三位科学家获得了诺贝尔物理学奖。 (美联社);
;

;周二，三位欧洲物理学教授因其在允许科学家研究电子的系统方面的工作而获得诺贝尔奖。

;

;电子是三大物理学之一。组成原子的粒子。

;

;然而，它们是如此之小，并且移动得如此之快，以至于科学家;;从未能够观察到它们。

; >;

;然而，法裔瑞典物理学家 Anne L'Huillier、法国物理学家 Pierre Agostini 和匈牙利出生的物理学家 Ferenc Krausz 的工作解决了这个问题。

;

;教授们进行的研究表明;超快光可以让科学家第一次“看到”电子。

;

;“你可以看到它是在分子的一侧还是另一侧，”L' 65 岁的惠利尔说。 “它仍然非常;模糊;。”

;
;;;诺贝尔奖获得者 Anne L'Huillier，今年的诺贝尔奖获得者之一物理学博士，在收到获奖通知后于 2023 年 10 月 3 日星期二在瑞典隆德的隆德大学举行了一场讲座。（阿伦·艾伦，美联社）;
;

;他们的工作产生的系统产生的光显示了围绕原子核的轨道上快速移动的电子。

;

;Krausz 的团队在 2000 年代初首次创造了短光脉冲。他说，该系统类似于具有快速;快门;速度的相机，允许摄影师在一级方程式赛车冲过终点线时捕捉到它。

;
;;;匈牙利裔奥地利物理学家费伦茨·克劳斯 (Ferenc Krausz) 向媒体发表讲话2023 年 10 月 3 日，在加兴马克斯普朗克研究所宣布 2023 年诺贝尔物理学奖获奖者后举行的会议。（摄影：CHRISTOF STACHE / 法新社）;
;

;使用另一个例子是带有光的特殊相机，可以清晰地看到蜂鸟快速翅膀运动的图像。

;

;但是电子的速度太快了，以至于无法在 ;科学家;进行的实验表明，可以在五分之一秒内产生;闪光;。

;

;诺贝尔委员会的马茨·拉尔森 (Mats Larsson) 表示，电子是原子的“劳动力”。 “一旦你能够控制和理解电子，你就向前迈出了一大步。”

;
;;;诺贝尔物理学委员会成员马茨·拉尔森 (Mats Larsson) 在宣布 2023 年诺贝尔物理学奖获奖者时向媒体发表讲话Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences in Stockholm on October 3, 2023. (Photo by Jonathan NACKSTRAND / AFP);
;

;The method to study electrons should help scientists develop better electronic devices or study molecules for medical purposes .

;

;L'Huillier is the fifth woman to receive the physics Nobel. She said her work is important because electrons are “how the atoms ;bind; together,” and where the chemical reactions happen.

;

;She said she spent 30 years working on the project, and she wants other scientists to keep working on “;fundamental; science” no matter how it might be used in the future. It did not become clear how her work would be used in “the real world” until many years passed.

;

;L'Huillier was in the middle of teaching a class at Lund University in Sweden when she got the news. “It's incredible,” she said. She went back to teaching the class after being told of the prize.

;

;Agostini is a retired professor at ;The Ohio; State University. Krausz is a professor at the Max Planck Institute in Germany.

;
;;;Scientist Pierre Agostini poses during an interview with Reuters after winning the 2023 Nobel Prize in Physics in Paris, France, October 3, 2023. REUTERS/Clotaire Achi;
;

;“I did not expect it,” Krausz said. “I am ;overwhelmed;,” he added, asking if he was “in reality or it's just a long dream.”

;

;Agostini was in Paris when the news was announced but did not get a call from the Nobel Committee. He suggested the Nobel group was looking for him Columbus, Ohio, where Ohio State is located.

;

;The 82-year-old said the prize was “good, but a bit late for me.”

;

;L'Huillier experimented with how a laser affects atoms in a gas causing electrons to produce light. Krausz worked on creating a system that could detect a single, very fast light ;pulse;. Agostini was able to investigate a series of very fast pulses.

;

;All the experiments showed that it would be possible one day to observe an image captured in an extremely small ;fraction; of a second, known as an attosecond.

;
;;;French-Swedish physicist Anne L'Huillier, who is one of this year's Nobel laureates in physics, celebrates with students and colleagues at Lund University, in Lund on October 3, 2023. (Photo by Ola TORKELSSON / TT NEWS AGENCY / AFP);
;

;Physics is the second Nobel Prize of the week. Two scientists earned the medicine prize on Monday for their work on mRNA that led to COVID-19 vaccines.

;

;Chemistry, literature, ;peace; and economics come next.

;

;I'm Dan Friedell.

;

;;Dan Friedell adapted this story for Learning English based on a reports by the Associated Press and Reuters.;

; Wed, 04 Oct 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Pope Opens Gathering to Discuss Future of Catholic Churchhttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/pope-opens-gathering-to-discuss-future-of-catholic-church/7294825.html
;;Tue, 03 Oct 2023 21:58:00 GMT;
;;
;;Pope Francis attends the prayer vigil in Saint Peter's square at the Vatican, September 30, 2023. (REUTERS/Remo Casilli);
;

;Pope Francis on Wednesday is opening a gathering of bishops and others to discuss the future of the Roman Catholic Church. Some of the discussions include subjects that have never been considered before.

;

;For the first time, women and non-clergy can vote alongside bishops in what is called a Synod of Bishops. The change reflects Francis' belief that the Church is more about its people than its leaders.

;

;The gathering, called a synod, starts on October 4 and will end on the 29. It will be followed by a second gathering next year. The second synod is expected to put forward detailed proposals for Francis to consider in a future document.

;

;The synod will have 365 voting members including the pope and 54 women. Their numbers are chosen by national bishops' organizations and religious orders.

;

;In addition, there are around 100 experts and “;facilitators;,” who will help move the discussion along. But they will not vote on a final document.

;
;;;Faithful gathered for the traditional Sunday noon blessing in St. Peter's Square at The Vatican cheers at Pope Francis appearing at his studio's window, Sunday, Oct. 1, 2023. (AP Photo/Riccardo De Luca);
;

;;What will be discussed?;

;

;The working document for the gathering came after two years of listening to concerns from Catholics around the world. The aim has been to raise questions and start a debate.

;

;For example, the document calls for specific steps to ;promote ;women to decision-making positions in the church. And it calls for church members to have more influence in church governance.

;

;It also suggests the “inclusion” of LGBTQ+ Catholics and measures to prevent clergy from abusing their power.

;
;;;Future cardinals arrive for a ceremony to create 21 new cardinals at St. Peter's Square in The Vatican on September 30, 2023. (Photo by Filippo MONTEFORTE / AFP);
;

;;Conservative concerns;

;

;Some conservatives have raised questions about the synod since Francis announced it three years ago. They said that those questions have already been settled by church teachings. And raising the questions only risks division among church members.

;

;Just this week, five conservative cardinals from Europe, Asia, Africa, and the Americas made their disagreement with Pope Francis public.

;

;In a letter, they put forward five questions, or “dubia,” asking Francis to ;affirm; church teaching on these issues, including homosexuality and female clergy. They said the synod was creating ;confusion;.

;

;Francis answered that changes in the world help the church to better understand and explain its teachings and that the synod is a way to find the path forward.

;

;“With much sincerity, I tell you it's not good to be afraid of these questions,” Francis told them.

;

;;A closed synod;

;

;For two years, the preparation for the synod has been open to the public. However, the synod itself will be closed to outsiders.

;

;There will be no live stream of the gathering. Organizers say it will be a closed-door meeting and those taking part have been told not to speak to reporters. No daily briefings are planned as in earlier synods although five briefings are expected to take place over the time of the gathering.

;

;Francis has defended the measures. The pope said he did not want “political ;gossip;” leaking out with news of attendees arguing over disputed issues.

;

;“This isn't a television show,” he told reporters in August.

;

;I'm Anna Matteo.

;

;

;

;;Nicole Winfield reported this story for the Associated Press. Hai Do adapted this report for VOA Learning English. ;

;

; Wed, 04 Oct 2023 06:07:03 +0800 How A Rural US School System Makes Gains in Mathhttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/how-us-rural-school-system-gains-in-math-/7277792.html
;;Tue, 03 Oct 2023 22:05:23 GMT;
;;
;;Piedmont math teacher Cassie Holbrooks helps a small group of fourth-grade students with a math problem in Piedmont, Ala., on Aug. 31, 2023. (Trisha Powell Crain/AL.com via AP);
;

;Many students across the United States fell behind in math during the COVID-19 pandemic. Many educators are seeking ways to bring students back up to usual math levels.

;

;Such efforts paid off for a rural school system in the southern state of Alabama. It has shown major improvement.

;

;A study called the Nation's Report Card shows that Alabama students led the nation in ;maintaining; math learning during the pandemic. And the state's Piedmont City school system landed at the top in a comparison of scores from before and during the pandemic. Nationwide, students on average fell half a year behind in math, researchers say.

;

;The Piedmont school system has about 1,100 students. Seven out of 10 children receive reduced-cost or free meals in the schools.

;

;The school system has stuck with a policy it established before the pandemic: Teachers use test scores to learn where students are struggling and then target teaching to each child.

;

;“We made a total ;transformation; about five years ago,” said Mike Hayes, the school system's chief. “We decided that we were going to let data make every decision.”

;

;Targeted ;instruction; for small groups of students has years of research and evidence to back it up, said Rebecca Dreyfus of the educational nonprofit TNTP.

;

;“The short answer is that using data effectively and efficiently to plan and ;monitor; instruction is always going to make instruction better for kids,” Dreyfus said.

;
;;;Piedmont Elementary School math teacher Cassie Holbrooks works with a small group of fourth grade students in Piedmont, Ala., on Thursday, Aug. 31, 2023. The rest of her class is working independently. (Trisha Powell Crain/AL.com via AP);
;

;Piedmont students were 35th in math skills for the state in 2017, when Hayes became the school system's leader. By spring 2022, Piedmont's students had moved to the 12th position.

;

;“Once we made that decision and stuck to it and made changes and ;allowed; our teachers time to look at the data and dive into the data, it paid off,” Hayes said.

;

;;Teachers go deep into data;

;

;As part of the effort, the Piedmont school system made the school day longer. This permitted time every four weeks for “data days,” when educators get together to study the numbers.

;

;Cassie Holbrooks teaches fourth-grade math. She said the “data days” help teachers see where the weaknesses are and target instruction.

;

;Sixth-grade teacher Lisa Hayes joined the school system five years ago. She said she was surprised to see how hard teachers worked during the data days.

;

;“When I came here and we had a workday,” she said, “you don't sit in your room. You're in here (the media center) most of the day, digging through test scores.”

;

;Teachers then use the information to decide how to divide the students into small groups for targeted instruction.

;

;Grouping two to six students together to work on a specific skill has long been used for reading instruction and in younger grades. There is less research on the use of targeted small group instruction in math. But researchers like Dreyfus say it involves the same idea of identifying students who need extra help, rather than simply pulling out children who are “behind.”

;
;;;Math teacher Cheyenne Crider helps a seventh-grade student with a math problem at Piedmont Middle School in Piedmont, Ala., on Thursday, Aug. 31, 2023. (Trisha Powell Crain/AL.com via AP);
;

;;Small groups and independent work;

;

;While math teachers in Piedmont schools work with small groups, other students write in their math books, play learning games, or work on individual learning plans.

;

;At first, when Piedmont expanded small group instruction in math, teachers said they did not have enough time to do the work well, Hayes said. So the schools expanded math and English language study time to between 80 and 120 minutes each day.

;

;The longer math classes made a big difference, teacher Landon Pruitt said. “In a 52- or 53-minute class,” he said, “there's no way you can ;consistently; do (small groups) and work on getting through the ;standards; that you have to cover.”

;

;The schools also had to help teachers ;adjust; classroom management techniques as small groups and independent work would be done at the same time. Hayes said one solution was to give teachers a program to monitor each students' screen. The district wants to make sure teachers have the support and resources to do the job well, he added.

;

;“I'm not sure we have a secret sauce or anything…” Hayes said. But, he noted that the teachers believe in learning data, and letting that data direct instruction.

;

;I'm Caty Weaver.

;

;

;

;;Trisha Powell Crain reported this story for AL.COM and The Associated Press. Hai Do adapted the story for VOA Learning English.;

; Wed, 04 Oct 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Guinean Student Rides across Africa to Get to Schoolhttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/guinean-student-rides-across-africa-to-get-to-school/7290396.html
;;Mon, 02 Oct 2023 21:55:36 GMT;
;;
;;Mamadou Safaiou Barry, a 25-year-old from Guinea, walks to the center where he studies Islam and the Koran, in El Marg district, east of Cairo, Egypt, September 23, 2023. (REUTERS/Fatma Fahmy);
;

;Mamadou Safaiou Barry lives in the West African nation of Guinea. He wanted to study Islamic ;theology; at a top school in Cairo, Egypt.

;

;Without money to pay for transport, Barry drew a map of Africa and headed out on a used ;bicycle ;for the trip across the continent.

;

;Carrying only a change of clothes, a flashlight, and a small tool, the 25-year-old rode through jungles, deserts, and conflict areas in the hope of getting accepted to the school and finding a way to pay for it.

;

;Four months and seven countries later, he is in Cairo with a full ;scholarship; to Al-Azhar University. That is one of the world's oldest and most respected Sunni Muslim learning centers.

;

;"If you have a dream, stay with it and be strong," Barry said. "God will help you."

;

;Thousands of West Africans like Barry take risky journeys across the Sahara desert each year, searching for a better life. But many never make it. Nearly 500 people died or disappeared on West African migration routes last year, data from the International Organization for Migration shows.

;

;Barry decided the risk was worth the ;reward;.

;

;"I had to fight," Barry said last August in Chad.

;
;;;Mamadou Safaiou Barry, a 25-year-old from Guinea, practices writing words in Arabic in a sideways orientation in east Cairo, Egypt, September 23, 2023. (REUTERS/Fatma Fahmy);
;

;Barry rode about 100 kilometers each day. He rode through Mali, Burkina Faso, Togo, Benin, and Niger. He had to stop in N'Djamena, the Chadian capital because of the ongoing conflict in Sudan.

;

;He said he had already been detained three times - twice in Burkina Faso and once in Togo. There, security forces held him for nine days without charge before releasing him for $56.

;

;That was all of his money for the rest of the trip, he said.

;

;"I often slept in the ;bush; because I was afraid of people in the cities," Barry said. "I thought they would take my bike and hurt me."

;

;Barry's luck changed again in Chad. There, a local ;philanthropist;, who had read about his trip online, offered to fly him directly to Egypt and avoid the fighting in Sudan.

;

;Barry arrived in Cairo on September 5 and days later received a full scholarship to Al-Azhar.

;

;He intends to return to Guinea when his studies are complete, to spread the ;faith; that has taken him so far.

;

;"When I return to my country, I would like to be someone who teaches Islam and tells people how to do good things," he said.

;

;I'm Dan Novak.

;

;

;

;;Dan Novak adapted this story for VOA Learning English based on reporting from Reuters. ;

;;FILE - The Johor-Singapore Causeway lies empty in Johor Bahru, Malaysia, on Nov. 28, 2021. The urgency for Southeast Asian nations to switch to clean energy to combat climate change is reinvigorating a 20-year-old plan for the region to share power. (AP Photo/Vincent Thian, File);
;
;

;Southeast Asian nations are increasingly looking to share power as a result of concerns about climate change.

;
;
;

;Malaysia and Indonesia signed a deal in Bali, Indonesia in August to study 18 possible areas where cross-border power lines can be set up.

;
;
;

;Those links could eventually create power equal to what 33 nuclear power plants would produce in a year. The links are economically and technically possible, and now are supported by ;regional; governments, said Beni Suryadi a power expert at the ASEAN Center for Energy in Jakarta, Indonesia.

;
;
;

;The Association of Southeast Asian Nations or ASEAN is a political and economic group of 10 countries across a large area. The group includes small countries such as Brunei and Singapore as well as larger ones such as Indonesia and Vietnam.

;
;;;FILE - Power lines are seen near a power plant near Dengkil on the outskirt of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Sept. 11, 2023. (AP Photo/Vincent Thian);
;
;
;

;Cross-border power purchases accounted for just 2.7 percent of the region's; capacity; in 2017, says the Global Interconnection Journal. But those were between two countries, such as Thailand and Laos.

;
;
;

;Now, more countries are looking at power sharing as a way to move their economies away from coal and other; fossil fuels;. Vietnam would like a regional; grid; so it could sell clean energy from offshore wind to its neighbors. And the Malaysian area of Sarawak is looking to sell its ;hydropower; to neighboring Indonesia.

;
;
;

;The plan for a regional grid between the 10 ASEAN members was developed twenty years ago, but progress has been slowed by problems including technical barriers and political mistrust.

;
;
;

;The region now recognizes it must move faster. Climate change could reduce the region's economic growth by more than a third by the middle of the century, a report presented at the 2021 UN climate conference in Glasgow, Scotland says.

;
;
;

;Demand for electricity is rising, and governments have realized the move away from fossil fuels requires an interconnected grid, Suryadi observed. “It has become a; crucial; need for every country,” he said.

;
;
;

;In the past, countries in the region paid more attention to energy security. They used fossil fuels and often built more capacity than they needed.

;
;
;

;But renewable energy costs are falling, making hydroelectric, solar and wind power more affordable. All ASEAN countries apart from the Philippines have promised to stop adding carbon to the atmosphere by 2050.

;
;
;

;So, arguments in favor of an interconnected grid appear to be winning.

;
;
;

;But issues remain.

;
;
;

;One of ASEAN's central policies is non-;interference;, which means members are less likely to do joint projects. Energy needs within a country sometimes conflict with the interests of an interconnected grid.

;
;
;

;Nadhilah Shani, another expert at the ASEAN Center for Energy, said that this creates a difficult position for some countries. The countries could sell clean energy to neighbors for the region to move away from fossil fuels, or they could use those resources to meet their own climate targets.

;
;
;

;The region's lack of a legal agreement for such things as setting submarine power cables is another difficult issue.

;
;
;

;Not all the technical problems have been solved. ;Voltages; used by each country can differ, as do the capacities of their grids. Even countries whose grids cross borders, like Thailand, need to upgrade them, said Harald Link, president of Thailand's Association of Private Power Producers.

;
;
;

;“You need a huge amount of electricity— and they want it green. And where do you get it from? For some countries, it is more difficult to make it green,” Link said.

;
;
;

;I'm John Russell.

;
